tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: This Can-Do is well-written. It has all 4 components, which makes it easier for a learner to envision doing this task. The context “to a friend” is not necessary for students to carry out this task; however the specificity does help students understand the level of formality of language they would need for this task.

answers.text: I can explain to a friend how to make a sandwich using simple sentences.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: This Can-Do does not have a measurable function. “Understand” does not clarify what the learner can do with the language, since their understanding cannot be observed. Instead, we could write “I can follow a sandwich recipe from a beginner cookbook.”

answers.text: I can understand how to make a sandwich from a simple recipe.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: This Can-Do does not have context nor text type. It is too broad. Although a Novice-level learner might be able to explain how to make a very simple recipe like a sandwich, the same learner would not be able to explain how to make a very complicated recipe like a Soufflé. Furthermore, the context of to whom or where they are presenting this explanation will impact the appropriateness of the task for a particular proficiency level.

This objective has two distinct functions (follow a recipe and make a video). It needs to be separated into two objectives and then the context and text type need to be clarified to make them each more specific and measurable.

answers.text: I can follow a sandwich recipe from a cookbook and then make a video explanation of how to make the sandwich.
